API Reference#

Control-oriented Dynamic Computational and Modeling Platform (CDCM)

Type of Nodes#

class Node(*, name: str = 'unamed_node', description: str = '', children: NodeSet = [], parents: NodeSet = [], owner: Optional[Any] = None, **kwargs)[source]#

A node in a graph.

Parameters

  • children – The children of this node. The nodes that this node is affecting.

  • parents – The parents of the node. The nodes that are affecting this node.

  • owner – The owner of the node - if any. In our application this is a system

  • name – The name of the object. The user must definitely provide a name.

  • description – The description of the object. Optional.

  • ignored. (Extra keyword arguments are) –

class Variable(*, value: Optional[Any] = None, units: str = '', track: bool = True, **kwargs)[source]#

Defines a CDCM variable.

The variable knows its units. It has a decscription that explains what it is. It has a name. And it has a value.

Parameters

  • value (int) – The value of the variable. Must be an int, a double or a numpy array of ints or floating point numbers. We also allow it to be a string. Initially, no value is specified. We are not going to check for the value of variables. But keep in mind that for saving them in files, the type has to be constant through out the life of the object.

  • units (str) – Must be a string or a pint object that describes an SI physical unit. This is optional as some variables may not have units.

  • track (bool) – A boolean. If True the variable will be tracked during simulations. If False it will not be tracked.

See Node for the rest of the parameters.

class Parameter(*, value: Optional[Any] = None, units: str = '', track: bool = True, **kwargs)[source]#

A class representing a parameter of a system.

See Quantity for the keyword arguments.

Systems#

class System(nodes: NodeSet = {}, **kwargs)[source]#

A system represents a set of nodes.

The nodes may be any class that inherits from Node.

The system satisfies the following attributes:

  • The system owns its nodes.

  • The system exposes its nodes as attributes.

add_node(obj)[source]#

Add a node.

property dag#

Turns the system to a directed acyclic graph.

Assumption:

No more nodes have been added to the system since the last time that this was called.

If you want to add more nodes after having added this, you have to make a new system object.

define_internal_nodes(**kwargs)[source]#

Define the internal nodes of the system.

Overload this when defining a new system by inheriting from this class.

property direct_nodes#

Get the nodes that are directly owned by this system.

property evaluation_order: Tuple[cdcm.node.Node]#

This is the order in which the graph should be evaluted.

Note that only Functions can be evaluated. So, this returns only functions.

Assumption:

No more nodes have been added to the system since the last time that this was called.

If you want to add more nodes after having added this, you have to make a new system object.

forward()[source]#

Moves all systems forward().

static get_context()[source]#

Get the current context.

static get_contexts()[source]#

Get the context stack.

get_nodes_of_type(Type)[source]#

Get nodes of Type.

property graph#

Turn the system to a directed graph.

This is not necessarily acyclic. It is used for visualization purposes.

For computational purposes, use dag.

static in_context()[source]#

Returns true if we are currently in a context.

property nodes#

Get all the nodes that are inside this system.

Note that this does not return subsystems, but the nodes of the subsystems. If you want to get the subystems, please use the subsystems property.

remove_node(obj: cdcm.node.Node)[source]#

Removes a node from the system.

Returns the name of and the object that was just removed.

property subsystems#

Return the subsystems of this system.

to_dict()[source]#

Turn the object to a dictionary of dictionaries.

transition()[source]#

Calls transition() on all nodes.
